page.title: 11ECOLOGY 2
page.content: continued from page 10 The soil is acid but at the eastern end of the woods it is enriched with lime, so many lime loving plants grow there. e.g. hair sedge, yellow saxifrage and grass of Parnassus, unusual in an acid environment.Roe deer graze here and there is a wide range of birds including snipe, woodcock and capercaillie as well as many smaller species. This is one of the best semi-natural woodlands on the Black Isle and it is a site of regional importance. Udale Bay is one of several bays along the Cromarty Firth, which is an area of international scientific interest. The bay covers 1280 acres and is now a National Nature Reserve. There are large tidal flats of sand, some mud and also a rocky beach running from Jemimaville and towards contd p 12
